div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, “Entombment," by Ciseri, and ‘Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Snakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hedeirab. Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah at call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.

div.head: A STORM IN A TEACUP.
div.p: Till very recently we regarded Alexandria as the habitat of a population of at least average intelligence and sanity. The evens of the last two days are calculated to alter our estimate of the menatal qualities of our fellow-citizen, however much they may do crédit rheir hearts, and the enthusiasm with which M. Canivet and his démonstrative friends hâve called upon the Egyptian Government and H. B. M.’s Agent and Consul-General to commit a violation of international law can only be described as worthy of a better cause.What are the facts? Three gentlemen of Jewish origin leave Russia, where their race has suffered cruel and unmerited persécution from an autocratic Government, and take up their résidence in Egypt, where their co-religionists would, we are convinced, hâve given them all the aid in their power. They are in a friendly country, secure from persecution, where their race is prosperous and respected, where political opinions of every shade, from Anarchism to Pan Islamism are freely expressed. They are men whom enthusiasm in the cause of liberty has brought into conflict with the grim représentatives of an autocratic Government and who have sought refuge in a country where a very respectable amount of freedom exists, where Anarchists, Mafiosi, Terrorists on the one hand, zealots for the Sultan of Stamboul and the most militant variants of Islam on the other, the Red Péril and the Black, can live secure from molestation if they refrain fron crime or incitement to violence. They an nonc the less arrested at the request of the Russian Consulats on the extremely grave charge of conspiring to blow up a Russian merchant steamer on the high seas by means of an infernal machine timed to explode outside territorial waters!

The crime which these men are accused of conspiring to commit is of a hellish atrocity. A steamer leaves port, the crew look forward cheerfully to the voyage, when the explosion of a dynamite bomb inflicts upon them well-nigh the certainty of agonising death from fire or scalding steam, or the slower pain of drowning. The sailors hâve taken no part in fusillades or executions. They are harmless soûls, whose worst crimes are drunken frolics, whose politics are those of the simple and unlettered, but the cruelty of some Governor and the rage of his victims doom them to a horrible and unexpected death coldly planned by their compatriote self-exilcd on a neutral shore.

Such is the offence of which these three Russian Jews are charged. Let them disprove it, let them explain their possession of explosives, and we shall be the first to rejoice in their acquittal. But let us at least abstain from dcecribing them as martyrs, let us avoid complimenting one of their number on being a member of the intellectual élite of Russia, till they be proved innocent of an attempted crime which prudence and humanity alike combine to re-probate. So much for the accused.

With their supporters, men of warm hearts and impulsive enthusiasm, we hâve no fault to find on moral grounds. Intellectually we feel impelled to do our best to break a lance with their champion, our esteemed confrère M. Raoul Canivet. M. Canivet has defended the Capitulations with wit and vigour, he has smiled régally and ironically at the challenges of the “three musketeers” of the “Progrès,” “Journal du Caire,” and “L’Egypte,” he has driven M. Colrat to threats of aviation, he has championed more causes-popular and unpopular than we hâve space to enumerate, often with success, always with the same fine and restrained irony and charm of style. But in the midst of his conflict for the Capitulations our excellent confrère pauses and from his trumpet “La Réforme” we hear the notes of

div.head: A STORM IN JANUARY Part 2
div.p: "about turn" A moment more and the good knight Raoul is riding lance in rest to the rescue of the three captive Russian Jews in thrall of Queen Capitualtions, mircaculously metamorphosed from a distressed Princess to an ogress of incredible ferocity. Never was the knighht of La Mancha more discomfited by enchantment and wizardry. And Sir Raoul's armies march from Bourse to Quay, from Quay to Consulate. A Russian sea captiain flies to his cabin from their advacne wishing that he had never protested against the possible loss of his ship with all hands. The descendants of the twelve tribes gather under the leadership of M. Campos, the Italian Socialists muster in their strength, amid cries of "No extradition" St. George is invoked in the person of Lord Cromer, on whom letters and telegrams rain incessantly, and the senior member of the seven champions is urgently requested to save the victims from the grasp of - but the reproduction of some of the epithets we have heard bestowed on the Russian Government might lead to an international incident.

Extradition! What does the word mean in Egypt, where for the purposes of criminal law the Englishman is in England, the Russian in Russia, and the Frenchman in France? The European criminal thanks, to those laws which M. Canivert defends, goes before his own courts, his own judges, is tried with the formalities under the procedure and by the legal code of his country. His status is unchanged. Let him murder a native of the country - he is handed over to his own judges. Should he disturb the public peace the janissaries of the Consulate are authorised, if it be needful, to call upon the Egyptain police to effect his arrest. This is no question of arbitrary, nor, if it were, could complaints alter the legal aspect of the situation. Our boursiers may demonstrate, our editors run-a-tilt, our Socialists rage, but the Law of the Capitulations shows an inexorable front to their appeals and attacks. Were such a charge concocted, were it a mere excuse for the arrest of political suspects, the accused would have by law to be handed over to his Consulate, unless indeed the Egyptian Government, undeterred by past experiences, violated the international agreements by which it is bound - and fettered. But the appeals to Lord Cromer? What competence has our Consul General in the matter of a foreign jurisdiction? By what right can he, of his own motion, call upon the Egyptian Government to intervene on behalf of the subjects of a foreign and friendly power? But Sir Raoul recks not of it. What matter diplomatic incidents, what to him are Conventions and Capitualtions, questions of law and questions of competence? With all a neophyte's ardour our Sicambrian knight adores what he burned and would burn what he adores. Meantime the telegrams fly on epa pteroenta adding appreciably to the budget, and the demonstrators demonstrate. If they are convinced of the innocence of the three prisoners, if they are sincere in their protestations of sympathy, let them send petitions to the Russian Consulate, but let them have the grace to refrain from calling on Egypt to rush blindly into an impasse.

div.p: A small dance will be given at Mena House on Wednesday, 23rd inst. A closed carriage serrvice will leave the hotel at midnight.

div.p: On Saturday night a fete will be held at the Grand Continental Hotel in celebration of the anniversary of the foundation of the Ottoman Empire.

div.head: Pierre Loti.
div.p: Commandant Visud has arrived at Port Said, and is staying at the Savoy Hotel. He will stay six months at Cairo as the guest of Mustapha Kamel. No doubt some contributions from Loti's brilliant pen will illuminate the columns of the "Egyptian Standard."

div.head: The Yost.
div.p: The Yost typewriter has been awarded the Grand Prix at the recent Bucharest International Exhibition. This award consists of a Diploma of Honour and Gold Medal, and is the only Grand Prix given in connection with typewriters at this exhibition.
Suicide or Accident?

John Johnson (28), a seamen on the S.S. Moorish Prince, disappeared from his ship in Alexandria harbour on Sunday last. Shortly afterwards bicap was found on the quay near the Mahmoudieh bridge, and it is surmised that he must have committed suicide or been accidentally drowned. His body has not yet been recovered.
Cercle Artistique.

A charming concert took place at the Cecle Artistque, Cairo, on Sunday afternoon. Mila Devilloy was the star of the entertainment and gave Micaela's air from the 3rd act of "Carmen" and the jewel song from "Faust" superbly. The orchestra conducted by M. Archibauld was admirable. Faure's music to Pelleus and Melisanda and Bonneau's prelude to Messidor being enthusiastically received.
St. Catherine's Club.

The fete given on Sunday in honour of Brothers, Idefonse, and George, founders of St. Catherine's Club. Alexandria was a groat success. The spacious hall of the college was crowded with many friends and old pupils who came to give a hearty reception after several years' absence to two educators of youth who have done so much for the welfare of the young in the town of Alexandria. Before the curtain was raised Mr. A. Sayour, president of the club, gave a speech welll suited to the occassion. He stated how one and all were pleased to see once more in their midst the two founders of the club. He showed the good the club was doing and hoped it would continue to shine among the many works of our city. Bro. Ildefonse responded at length thanking the members for their hearty reception. He was glad to see the work progressing and the good it was doing. Afterwards the curtain rose and a comic duo. "Souffloride and Grattamort," was sung by G. Brewer and G. Sanvise. Their singing and acitng were much appreciated. "Les guardiens de Phare," a drams in one act, kept the audience spell-bound for a full half hour. Many a heart was touched to see Pere Brehand (mr. Aime Pau) accomplishing his duty notwithstanding the critical state of his son Yvon (Mr. H. Lamon). Great credit is due to these two amatuers for their able performance. The comic songs of Mr. L. Bullet were so much liked that he was recalled the times. Mr. N. Capillo's monologue. "The Deserter," was much applauded. Next followed a farce in Italien "La Tombols," which kept the audience in roars of laughter. Mr. P. Capillo played his part in splendid style. Mesars A. Mifaud. N. Capillo W. Azzopardi. R. Faro, and S. Noro also deserve a word or praise. The college orchestra was in good form and gave select pieces from its repertoire.

div.head: A HERO'S DEATH.
div.p: KILLED WHILE TOBOGANNING.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
LONDON, TUESDAY.

The death is annnounced of that well-known officer, Captain Singleton Pennell, V.C., whose name came prominently before the public during the Tirah campaign on account of his heoric conduct on the Dargai heights. He met his death in a terrible toboggan accident at San Moritzdorf.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Yesteday morning the Khedive visited the Ghizeh Zoological Gardens, where he remained about three hours. He afterwards returned to Abdeen Palacee, where he spent the day.

AMong those received in audience on Saturday by the Khedive were H.H. Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel, T.H. Princes Aziz Pasha Hassan and Ibrahim Pasha Hassan, H.H. the Grand Duke Boris of Russia, M. Klobukowaki, Baron de Villebois, Dr. Chaker Bey El Khoury. Herr von Mhol, Auguste Bey Adib, and Miralai Matchett Bey.

div.head: MINISTRY OF EDUCATION.
div.p: Our Tahta Correspondent telegraphs: H.E. Saad Pasha Zoghloul, Minister of Education, together with Soliman Bey Osman, Moudir of Ghirgheb, Abdallah Bey Wahhy, inspector of irrigation, and Sidky Bey, president of Assiout Native Court, arrived yesterday at Tahta and paid a visit today (Monday) to the Rifaah Pasha School. The minister examined the boys in the various subjects and expressed himself as being highly pleased. He thanked Mohamed Bey Rafaah for the care which he took of the school, and spoke words of encouragement to the teaching staff. On leaving for Assiout he delivered on the platform of the station an eloquent impressing on all the necessity of diffusing instruction and improving the condition of the Kuttabs.

div.head: MR. ROBERTSON M.P.
div.p: We have received a letter, dated the 20th inst, written from the National Hotel, Cairo, by Mr. J.M. Robertson. M.P., who informs us that the statement published in our edition of Saturday relative to Mr. Robertson's visit to the Coptic and Moslem school at Dirmish is incorrect. Mr. Robertson informs us that (1) he did not visit the school in the company of a sheikh accused of uttering is inflammatory harangues; (2) the head-master of the school is a Copt and not a Morlem; and (3) he asked the pupils 10 questions relative to fanaticism, etc.

Mr. Robertson has our sympathy and regret. The Press teems with allusions to his journeys and his utterances, cunards abound, and we hope that in future M.P.'s visiting Egypt on a political or quassi-political errand will supply the future Press Association of Egypt with accurate and authentic details. We understand that "Al Lew's" recent statement Mr. Robertson's views on the police school is totally unfounded.

div.head: NEW BOOK ON EGYPT.
div.p: There have been 30 many books written about Egypt during the past ten or fifteen years that it might seem well nigh impossible for anyone to find an excuse for adding to the number, but we learn that Mr. T. Finbor Unwin, the well known publisher of London, whose name in a book is a guarantee that the author is one entitled to a hearing upon whatever his subject may be, has sent to press a volume for which it is claimed that it stands apart from all the other books on Egypt or Egyptian matters in more respects than one. In the first place, the book we speak of is an attempt to show how the Egyptians look upon European civilisation and the Occupation, and in the next, it is written by a man who has an absolutely unique experience ot the East and its Moslem peoples to guide him. To these advantages it may be added that it is written in a graphic, nervous style, abounding with illustrative allusions and references, and will undoubtedly prove one of the most readable of the books of the year. The book is, indeed, from all we bear, one that might stand wholly upon its own merits, but the fact that its author is known to have devoted himself for many years to the stndy of Islam and its relations to the British Empire, gives it a special importance as a contribution towards our knowledge of Egypt and its people. We may add that, as might be expected, it pays the highest tribute to Lord Cromer and his work. With all this it is a book that will probably give rise to some criticism and discussion, for the author's views are bodly expressed, and so, while satisfied that it will prove a book eminently worth reading, we at the same time reserve our right to criticise it when once it is in the hands of the public.

div.head: M. THERY ON MODERN EGYPT.
div.p: M. Elmond Tiery has now published in book form the series of articles on modern Egypt which he centributed to his "Economiste Europeau" - "L'Egypte Nouvelle" (this is the title of the volume) - which constitutes an historical compilation. What particularly strikes the reader of the book is that M. Thery is impartially itself in dealing with the matter.
Illegible

div.head: RUSSIAN TERRORISM.
div.p: THE ALEXANDRIA PLOT.

We understand that the following are the facts relative to the arrest of the three Russian Jews, which has called forth the easily-aroased factiousness tor which Alexandria has been notorious since the days of Hadrian.

It appears that about a fortnight ago the Russian Consulate at Alexandria had reason 1 to believe that the three individuals in question, Boteoff, alias Mishka, Shureeu, and Vopouls, were contemplating the perpetration of an act affecting public security. Botsoff, a Russian subject, condemned to death in Russia, was the leader of this little group of Terrorists, who had resolved to show their sympathy with the Russian revolutionary parties and to strike terror into the autocracy by what Nihilists describe as "a blow for freedom" and ordinary individuals as a “bomb outrage." The Egyptiau police were accordiugly warned, and maintained a dose surveillance of the three Terrorists.

Their purchase of certain metals and chemical products usually employed by private manufacturers ot high explosives was in itself , sufficient to arouse tbe graven suspicions, and suspicion deepened to certainty when the Captain of the Russian steamer, S.S. ,

received a letter from Botsoff, asking him to hand over fire thousand roubles to the boatswain of his vessel to be paid into the funds of the Russian Revolutionary Society of Alexandria, failing which he would be disposed of and his ship destroyed.
The Captain made no reply and the boatswain was informed by Botsoff that his failure to meet the demand would be severely punished.

It is not surprising that the Russian Consulate, at Alexandria was indisposed to pass , lightly over this alarming species of blackmail. The Egyptian Police were requested by Mr. d’Abaza, the Russian Consol, to assist the consoler janissaries in the arrest of the three revolutionaries, who appear to have opened farther negotiations with the boatswain and were discovered in conversation with the wily tar at the “Stamboul” coffee-house. They were promptly taken into custody and a police search resulted in the discovery both of incriminating documents and materials for the fabrication of explosives.

We are informed that Botsoff’s plan was to depo-it in the engines of the Russian steamer a bomb or infernal machine, timed to explode about two hours after the vessel had left port,—an ingenious method of ensuring the destruction of the vessel with great loss of life. Those who are familiar with descriptions of boiler explosions or have read accounts of the effect of a shell in the engine rooms of warships can easily realise what horrors would have followed the explosion.

We have in our leading article alluded to the legal aspects of the case. We may add that the appeal to Lord Cromer was in such a case an extraordinary tactical error. Let us assume for the sake of argument that a French Anarchist had attempted to display his hatred of the bourgeois Republic by p’acing a bomb in the bunkers of one of the Messageries Maritimes steamers; how would the French Government and the French colony in Egypt regard tbe intervention on behalf of the prisoner of any member of the Diplomatic Body? There can be no two opinions about the answer. They would be indignant, and justly so.
FEELING AT CAIRO.

The excitement at Alexandria has had its effect on Cairo, though beyond good-humoured demonstrations there has been noo kind of disorder in the Capital. A well attended meeting, consisting principally of stockbrokers, was held at the Continental Hotel yesterday afternoon, the chief speakers being Messrs. Voronoff, Rossi, Chalon, and Petrachi. After Mr. Voronoff speech, counselling a pacific consideration of the question of arrest and extradition, the meeting became merely a babble of voices. Here and there some impetuous youth would demand a forcible descent upon the Russian Consulate or British Agency, but that proposal was promptly quashed, and finally a committee was formed to interview the Russian Minister.

We understand that the committee was informed that the Russian Minister could only uphold the laws of his country, but that a serious enquiry would beheld concerning the charge brought against the prisoners, and that these would not be extradited for some days.

Later in the afternoon, together meeting was held at the Theatre des Nonveautes, but the discussion was too general and too heated for any resolution to be passed Both meetings in fact resolved themselves into excited discussions among the lawyers who were present, with frequent interruptions by others of the audience.
A similar meeting was held at the New Bar about 11 p.m. It was noticeable that from 8 o’clook upwards the number of police in the vicinity of the Russian Consulate was considerably increased.

This afternoon, at 12.30, a large meeting was held outside tbe Bourse. Some hundreds must have been present, and after an in audible speech, delivered in Italian the crowd proceeded to march to the Russian Consulate, where there was a loud but harmless demonstration, after which they moved on to the Ministry of the Interior.

div.head: CAIRO'S GARDEN CITY.
div.p: Several of the very best plots of this estate are offered, at very reasonable rates, by Mr. C. Aquilina, Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley.

div.head: BANK OF ABYSSINIA.
div.p: NEGOTIATIONS WITH MENELIK.

Negotiations are now proceeding between the governing board of the Bank of Abyssinia and the Emperor Menelik, whose wishes the board are most anxious to meet both in their own interests and in that of the country. The board is endeavoring to come to an arrangement by which the management of the branch of Abyssinia may be delegated to a board of responsible administrators, sitting at Adis-Ahedba.

The rumours that have been current in Cairo to the effect that a new Governor of the Bank will be appointed in the place of Mr. MacGillivray are officially confirmed, and that gentleman will not return to Abyssinia.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND COMPANY.
div.p: Mr. Justice Parker, in the Chancery Division on Saturday week, sanctioned an extension of the memorandum of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Ltd., so as to allow the company to extend its operations to the Sudan on condition that the company altered its name in some way to indicate the alteration.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: The recent new issue of 235,143 shares of francs at par by the Corporation of Western Egypt has been a great success. There were one hundred thousand shares reserved for subscribers in this country. These were over subscribed for and the underwriters have been paid their commissions in full.

div.head: NEW APPOINTMENTS.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has appointed Mr. Algood director of the Police School, Cairo.
Ali Sidki Effendi has been appointed Mamour of Delingat Markex and Mohamed Hamdi Eff. Abou Zaid Mamour of Minieh Marks.

div.head: NILE TOURISTS.
div.p: List of passengers by the P.S. Amenartas, which left Cairo yesterday: Admiral Sir Nowell and Lady Salmon, Miss Salmon, Miss Staveley, Mrs. E.C. Balas. Miss M. Mackay, Miss E. Reid, Miss M. Cox, Miss M. Baker, Miss M. Talbot, Miss A. Hutton, Count and Countess de Germiny, Mr. Paul Hermann, Mr. and Mrs. Caroli.

div.head: "LA DANNAZIONE DI FAUST."
div.p: This music grows on one more each time one hears it. Last night's performance marked a distinct advance, especially for the chorus, which was notably in time throughout. M fitofele sang a splendid serenata, and Margherita, though physically fitted for rues demanding a maturer personality, has some fine and rich notes. The merriment of the house was ill suppressed when she turned on an ordinary electric light in her medieval chamber; nor are we surprised, for the thing is a flagrant outrage against stage illusion. The first interval was again monstrously and unduly prolonged, and served to impress us yet more deeply with the conviction that oratorios should not be dramatised, even if as in this case, a pantomine (Act III.) is thrown in .

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY. NOTICE.
div.p: Owners of bicycles, tricycles, motor cycles, and hand carts, including barrel organs, are informed that numbered plaques will be supplied to them free by the Municipality. For those who hold a plaque for 1906 a distinctive mark for 1907 will be added. Applications must be made to the Service des Reverttes before February 18, 1907, Sundays and holidays excepted, by the owners, so as to have the plaques or distinctive marks put on to their vehicles. After the above date, if any of the above mentioned vehicles are found circulating without a plaque or distinctive mark their owners will be liable to prosecution.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Imperial Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left London on the 20th inst, and is due at Alexandria on or about 5th February.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON MILLS, LTD.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
Sir,- In your issue of the 19th there appears a letter from one of your correspondents headed as above.

The figures given by him of the Profit and Loss account of this company ending 30th September 1906 are correct, but the description of these expenses has been altered and therefore calculated to misleady your readers. We should be obligd therefore if you will state the account exactly as it appears iin the report as follow:-
RECEIPTS.
By Profit on Manufacturer... 9,427.19.11
Sundries... 3.11
EXPENSE
Insurance, Taxes, Selling ex's, Cairo... 1,737.11.07
Excise Duty... 3,915.08.04
Administration expenses, England and Egypt
Directors' Fees... 240
Rent, Secretary's salary and Audit Fees... 444.11.10
Travelling expensses... 156.-.2
General expenses... 241.5-
Interest and discount... 3,611.15.10
(Including Interest paid on debit balances to Bank and Mortgages)
Difference. Loss for the year... 930.-.1
We hand you copy of report here with. The particulars of the balance sheet were correctly given.

Your correspondent also remarks as to a London Board. The London Board of this company retired in favour of a local board three years ago. The only official of the company in England is the Secretary, Mr. Spedding. The Profit and Loss a/c distinctly says administrative expenses England and Egypt and not administrative expenses in London, as your correspondent writes.- Yours truly,
For the Egyptian Cotton Mills, Ld.
A.H. Pratt,
Manager and Local Secretary.
Cairo, January 20.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,- The present agitation brings into startling relief the question of Capitulations, so recently defended with great energy by your contemporary, who now is one of the first to raise the movement to avoid them in the present instance.

They are undoubtedly very awkward for political offenders, who should avoid Egypt. The argument and cries so often raised now, of "Liberty" and "Let us be free" and "Such a surrender would not be permitted in England," are all useless, as in European countries a foreigner charged with conspiracy (rightly or wrongly) would be tried by the European Courts first, a procedure the Capitulations do not permit here; here political refugees risk having charges brought against them to bring them to trial by their own officials and thus be repatriated, so that your "Liberty," etc, must come from where the Italian Chamber of Commerce for one, fears to step, "the abolition of the Capitulations." - Yours faithfully,
R.C.A.
Alexandria, 22nd January.

div.head: THE SERCANT QUESTION IN EGYPT.
div.p: To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette ” Sir,—In reference to the second letter from “An Old Resident” in your issue of the 19th, may I suggest that he and any others of your readers who are interested in that important question should communicate with me as undersigned c/o. "The Egyptian Gazette” Office, Alexandria, and I would endeavor to arrange a meeting at an early date in Cairo of those interested fully to discuss what steps can be taken on the lines that have been suggested. Otherwise I fear the question will merely degenerate into an expression of opinion in the newspapers, and will die a natural death. I am, etc,
"ANOTHER OLD RESIDENT."
Cairo, January 20.

Sir, - With reference to the above, which was the subject of recent correspondence in your valuable paper, we beg to state that we are quite in sympathy with "Old Resident" and "Sufferer on this important question, and, as we are just commencing a business as commission and general agents, we should be very pleased to take up this question, as suggested by your correspondents in your issues of the 11th and 15th inst. respectively providing sufficient support is forthcoming from the European community, We should feel obliged if either "Old Resident" or "Sufferer" would afford us any further information they can on the subject, i.e., by whom the present Goanese servants are employed, and whom we could communicate with in Bombay, with a view to making full enquiries and importing there servants.
We should also feel greatly honoured if any European subject who is in favour of and willing to support this scheme will kindly communicate with us. We are, etc, W. KING & Co.
Kaar-el-Nil Cairo.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Among the distinguished passengers staying at Shepheard'- Hotel are:-H.R.H. Priuz Frariz of Bavaria, H.I.H. the Grand Duke Boris of Russia, H.H. Prince Djemil Tonsoun, the Duke de Bensvente, the Duke of Medinecv, H.H. Pricne de Creanze, H.H. Princes de Brancovau, H.H. Prince d'Arocans, Com'e de Bridges, Baron vou Reichlin, Munich. Count Wachtmeister, Countess Wachtmeister, Baron de Borg, Baron von Heffels, Com'esse de Montjoys, Comtesse de Castelmenardo, Baron von Schiweinitz, Comtesse de Castelmenardo, Baron von Schweinitz, Comtesse de Castelmenardo. Baron Von Schweinitz. Comtesse da Rykaiviez, Comte Francis Thurm, Comte de Knisky, Baron de Crombrughe, Baroness de Crombraghe. Baron Empain, Baron and Baroneis de Griffier.
Prince Djemil Toussoun will pass Kourban Beyram at Luxor.
The Prince of Udina and suite arrived at Cairo yesterday. The Prince is staying at the Savoy Hotel. The Khedive and the Prince exchanged visits in the course of the afternoon.

The Earl and Countess of Carnarvon, who have been entertaining a number of guests at their Hampshire seat, Highclere Castle, near Newbury, propose leaving England for Egypt towards the end of this month.
Lord and Lady Newborough are due at the Savoy today.
Count Moarkerke, the well-known Belgian noble, add a party Sir Hamilton Lang, Lady Copper and Baroness de Forest are due at the Savoy shortly.
General Cherif Pasha, Turkish Ambassador at Copenhagen, Count and Countess Holstein of Bavaria, and M. Fould, the French multimillionaire, have arrived at the Savoy.
Sir Ernest Cassel is arriving at Cairo next week and is putting up at the Savoy.
Lady Cooper is coming out to join Sir Alfred Cooper at Cairo. Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Ashley are also paying a visit to Egypt.
Lady Huntingdon, widow of the late Sir Charles P. Huntingdon, and the members of her family are leaving England this week for Egypt where they will stay for some months.
Sir Hamilton Lang and party of six arrived to day at the Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, which is now “an complet”.
Sir George Doughty. M.P. for Grimsby, has left England for a tour in the East, which will include a visit to Egypt.
Mr. Felix Cobbold, M P. for Ipawich, will also shortly leave England for Egypt. The hon. member hopes to reach Khartoum.
Mr. Machel1, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, returned to Cairo yesterday from the Fayoum.
Biron Max O.tpenbeim gave a dance at Lie Cairo residence last night

The following were the passengers for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe last night: The Grand Duke Boris and party, Mr. Bond, Mr. Haines, Mr. Anderson. Mr. Boulos Boutros, Mr. Kostrowiztke, Sir Robert Dashwood, Mr. and Mrs. Elliot, Miss Wollner, Mr. and Mrs. Hutchinson, Mr. Aslan Dassan, Mr. David Saltoun, Mr. Pollach.

Our Luxor correspondent writes that a distinguished and artistic coterie may always be found at the Savoy Hotel, just now. The visitors include Dr. Henry Goudy, Regius Professor of Civil Law at the University of Oxford, end Mr. A. O. Lamplough, the well-known artist.
M. Joannia Polomis, the poet laureate of Greece, is in Cairo, and is coming here soon to give a recital of his work.
Mrs. Butcher has received so many kind letters that she cannot, for the present, do more than offer her sincere thanks to the writers in general. They have been received very gratefully.
The death has occurred at Cairo of Mr. C. P. Redmond, proprietor and editor of the “Water-ford News.” In his younger days Mr. Redmond was an expert cyclist and oarsman.

div.head: TO REFORM BROKERS.
div.p: The miission that is intended to reform the brokers on the New York Stock Exchange began last week with a prayer meeting at the office of Mrs. J. A. Gaylord, a lady who conducts a prosperous broking business at 35, Wall-Street.

The Rev. H.M. Warren had intended opening his missions with a prayer meeting on the broad kerb in front of the Stock Exchange, but the police would not grant the necessary permission. It was then arranged that be he should begin at Mrs. Gaylord office.

As he was starting for Wall Street he received, says the "Express" correspondent, an unexpected call to marry the son of a Cincinnati brewer who had eloped with the coachman's daughter. Mrs. Cayford determined to have the prayers, however, and at ten o'clock she ordered work to stop in the office and telephoned to Mr. Warren.

Her clerks and clients gathered near the telephone, and at his hotel Mr. Warren read into the instrument a brief passafe from the Bible and offered a short prayer, in which he pleaded for guidance for brokers to deal honesetly by their clients.
Mrs. Gayford responded with a prayer of similar purport.

The effect of the new departure will be wateched with interest, particularly by European investors; but the question arises whether, in view of recent revelations, the New York Stock Exchange is not already past praying for.-"Financial News."

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie AVIS
div.p: La Municipalite met en adjunction la fourniture d'uniformes et antres articles d habillement necessaires a ses differents services pour la duree de trois annees.
Le cantionnement est fixe a L.Eg. 100.
Le cahier des charges est depose au Service de la Comptabilite Generale cu il peut etre consulte par les inte estes tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours feries exceptes.
Les offices devront etre adres eas sous pli cachete a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 5 Fevrier 1907.
Elles pourront egalement etre deposees enseance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour fournitures d'uniformes et autres articles d'habilment."

Le cantionement ou le reca d'une banque, d'apres les conditions du cahier des charges, devra etre remis separement au Serivce de la Comptabilite Generale avant l'overture des offres et au plus tard le 5 Fevrier 1907 a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci dessus sera ecartee.
L'Administrateur
(Signe) W.P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandria, le 16 Fevrier 1907. 29383 3-2

Les offres devront etre accompagrees d’nne feuille de papier timbré de 30 millièmes. Eiles seront adressées par la Poste sens pli recommande a:
“Monsieur le Directeur Général
Chemins de Per do l'Etat,
Le Caire.”
et sons double enveloppe, l'intérieore portant la suscription suivante:
"Offre pour Hnile de Graine de Coton.”
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'off e la pins basse ni à donner soite aux soumissions pré-enfées et elle se réserve le droit de diviser la commande.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Lundi 21 Janvier. Le taux de l'escompte libre a Lordres a ete encore e've samedi passe, de 1/8 a 4 7/8 pourcent. Au Stock Exchange le Consolide anglais a perdn 1/8 a 87. L'Unifee e'est maintenne a 102 ½ de meme que la National Bank a 28 ½ l'Agricole a 9 ¾ et la Delta Light a 12. La Daira a retrograde de 1/8 a 17 5/8.
A Paris, le Credit Funcier Egyptien a regagne 2 france a 778. La Banque d'Athenenes en a perdu 2 a 137.

Ici le marche a ete anjourd'hui, dans son ensemble, calme et indecis, avec affaires restreiutes et tendance a la lourdeur. I y a entoutefois un assez bon movement sur lea axtions et parts Excelsior Hotels, partts de fondateur Entreprises Immobilieres et Travaux, Nungovich Hotels, Jouissances Eaux du Caire, actions de parts Estates. La cloture a ete relativement faible sur preque toute la ligne de la cote.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a'est tassee a 23 3/16-1/4. L'Agricolo s'est maintenne a 9 5/8-11/16; on assure que le prochain dividende sera d'environ 8 sh. 6 contre 7 shi. 6 pour l'exercise precedent. La Cassa di Sconto a molli a 280 281 et le Comptoir Financier a 8 1/16. La Barque d'Abyssinie a faibli a 5 ¼ 5/16.

Le Credit Foncier a ete delaisse a 770; I'obligation a lots aucienne a avance a 3:1. La Daira est revenue a 17 ½. La Nile Land a recule a 17 5/8. Le Wardan Estate a ete ramene a 7 7/8 et sa part a 9 ½ L'Allotment estreste a 3 9/16 et sa part a 140. L'Immobliere retrograde a 393 et l'Enterprise and Development a 13 5/8.
L'action Entreprises Immobilieres et Travaux a ete negociee a 17 ¼; la part de fondateur, lagemept traitee, a avance de 302 a 318 pour c'oturer a 314.

L'Epargne Immobiliere a faibli a 3 15/16 sa part a flechi a 250. Catte depression s'explique par la livraison des titres, des parts de fondatuer notamment qui ont ete allouees a titre graxieux et que beaucoup de leurs detententeurs se sont empresses de vendre.

L'Express Nile a cloture a 5 ¾ et sa part a 360. Les Cairo Suburban sout restes aux abords de 6 et les parts Egyptian Mail a 4 3/1. Les parts de fondateur Societe Generale Egyptienne sout revenues a 108 francs.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire, assez mouvementees, ont perdu 5 francs a 291.

Dans le groupe des valeurs ho elieres, les Nungovich, au bonne tendance, out avance a 23 1/16-1/8. Les Egyptian ont fini a 12 ¾-13/16. Les Upper Egypt out re rograde a 4 7/8. Les National se sont maintenus a 3 15/16; leur part a cloture a 89. On s'attend a un tres proche mouvement surce titre, la nouvellle de la fusion de la Societe avec l'Anglo Egyptian Hotels Co tendant a se confirmer.
Tres bon mouvement sur les Exelsior qui, de 4 9/16, ont pas e a 4 13/16 pour reaction ner a 4 11/16; leur part a atteint L.E. 2 pour cloturer a 1 14/16.

Parmi les petites valerus, la Delta Land s'est maintenue a 4 3/8 et les Abdy a 1 5/16 3/8. Les Estates se ont tasses a 2 5/8-11/16; leur part a hausse a 22 ¾. Les New Egyptian se sont bien tenus a 31 sh, 9-32 et les Markets a 30 sh Les Salt and Soda out flechi a 21 sh. 6 Les Hooker out faibli a 1 3/16-1/4.

L'assemblee generale extraordinaire de l'Express Nile Steamers Co, tenue avant hier soir an siege social au Caire n'syant pos reanile nombre des voix requis stat tairement pour les deliberations, est conviquee a nouveasu pour le mercredi 6 Fevrier 1907, a 4 heures p.m. O dre de jour: augmentation du capital.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, “Entombment," by Ciseri, and ‘Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
P: Sohnack, Proprietor
Level Wooded Walks.

div.head: THE GRAND HOTEL LIDO.
div.p: Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Legune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address- SOCIETE BACHI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.

div.head: To the Printers of Egypt.
div.p: Salisbury Square.
Fleet Street. London. E.C.
Gentlemen.

TEN years ago we established in London the CAXTON TYPE FOUNDRY to manufacture Printing Types on the interchangeable time and labor-saving principles of Standard Point Line, and Point Set on Point Body. We claimed, and have established the statement. that the exclusive use of Canton Printing Types would style one-fourtth of the compositors time in the setting of all kinds of hand composition. At tha present time over 10.000 Printers in tha United Kingdom. Australasia. Canada. Africa, the Indian Empire and other British possessions are customers of tke Caxton Type Foundry.
As is well known, the type industry of America is controlled by a type TRUST and in tka United Kingdom by a similar organisation known as the type RING of British Type Manufacturers.

The CAXTON Type FOUNDRY was founded to oppose all suh combinations. It is independent of all such connections, and it therefore, telling type at a lower price, and furthermore, guarantees to sell at the same price in all parts of the British Empire.

Another branch is the CAXTON WOOD MILLS, the largest and most complete Wood Working Plant in the British Empire exclusively employed in the production of space and labour saving woodwork for Printers. We have made a speciality of using hard wood exclusively in all our productions. Wood Furniture and Reglet is made out of Tungstone a specially close-grained Wood which is so heavy that it sinks in water, sad is therefore particularly valuable.

We are also makers of the widest and this most complete rings of PLATEN PRESSES in tha World, comprising ha well-known "Caxton" Platan, for fine work; tha light-running "Swift" Platen for smalt printers: the Haddon "Improved Gordon." suitable for any jobbing printer: the Haddon " Safety Platen," capable of printing 2.500 full forms per hour: the Haddon "Improved Victoria," modelled on the Cropper principle, but superior in construction and output.
We invite enquiries, when complete Catalogues with all details will be sent
Yours, faithfully.
JOHN HADDON & CO.
Agent for Egypt 1 JEFFREY W EADY.
Charek Montes. Boulevard Mohamed Aly, Cairo.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Snakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hedeirab. Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah at call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalite met en adjudication la fourniture d'uniformes et antres articles d'habillement necessaires a ses differents service pour la duree de trois annees.
Le cautionnement est fixe a L. Eg. 100.
Le cahier des charges est deopose au Service de la Comptabili e Generale ou il peut etre consulte par les intereses tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours feries exceptes.
Les offres devront etre adres eas sous plicachate a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 5 Fevrier 1907.
Elles pourront egalement etre deporsees enreance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour fourniitures d'uniformes et autres articles d'habulment."

Le cantionnement ou le recu d'nne banque, d'apres les condtions du cahier des charges, devra etre remis se arement au Service de la Comptabillite Generale avant l'overture des offres et au plus tard le 5 Fevrier 1907 a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci dessus sera ecartee.
L'Administratuer
(Signe) W.P. CHATAWAY
Alexandria, le 16 Fevrier 1907. 29383-3-3

div.head: THE GERMAN CRISIS.
div.p: In spite of the sinister motives' which are so freely imputed to us in the Fatherland, the, English public will continue to take a growing interest in the German electoral struggle German politics form an exceedingly perplexing study, and the group system on which their Parliamentary majorities are based leads occasionally to some very surprising combinations. In the recently dissolved Reichstag there were something like twenty separate “parties,’ several of them, it is true, consisting of only a single representative. The most numerous section of all, the Catholic Centre, counted only 100 out of the total of 397 members, while the Social Democrats, who came next, had 81 But it should be added, that these 81 Socialists were returned by 3,000,000 votes, as against 1,900,000 cast for the Catholics’ electoral anomalies are not confined to the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. It is clear that the centrifugal tendency which kept Germany for so many years a more geographical expression has still to be eradicated. The German Empire has been unified by its Army and Navy, and stands. four square to foreign nations Internally, in the political arena at least, it is individualistic as ever, except in one quarter, where the solidarity and perfect electoral machinery of the Social Democrats form the main barrier to Imperial threats and cajolery. As the time for the polling draws, near the contest is narrowing itself down to a struggle between the Kaiser and the Socialists which may change the whole complexion of international politics.

The unprecedented efforts which are being put forward by the bureaucracy on behalf of their Imperial master are a significant indicatior of the light in which the elections are regarded at the heart of the Government. And in their extremity, the wire-pullers are directing their attention to the literary and professorial class, which has hitherto stood several) aloof from “Cessarism.”

This, of course, says the “Globe," is tge meaning of the “lecture” which was recently delivered by Herr Dernberg, the Colonial Director, to the In tellectuals of Berlin. The theme, naturally enough, was the Gerrnan Colonial Empire, and though the discount seems of a somewhat elementary character when the class of audience is taken into consideration, Herr Dernberg succeeded in evoking no small measure of enthusiasm. And as a practical result, the meeting resolver to appoint a committee, which “without directly intervening in the agitation of parties, would endeavour to extend and deepen the appreciation of colonial policy and ‘Welt politik' among the electorate." Some of the most distinguished names among the Prussiat Professoriate were promptly placed upon the list, and a campaign of lectures and leaflets is being rapidly prepared. We write in no carping spirit; this movement is projected on liner that are familiar to us Englishmen, and the enormous success of the German Navy League has shown what these voluttary organisations, can effect. Our chief criticism would be that, with a view to the present general election,the start has been made very late in the day. Moreover, the snare has been laid somewhat ostentatiously in the sight of the birds. The sudden enthusiasm of the Intellectuals for a colonial Empire is the subject of caustic comment in many of the German Radical papers ; and it is certainly somewhat remarkable that a sudden conversion should have been brought about by the academic and not very convincing arguments of the Colonial Director. Moreover, the Intellectuals are not held in any particular esteem just now by the leaders of active political thought in Germany, The fighting professors, like Mommsen and Virchow, have passed away, and no one has arisen to fill their place. The “Berliner Tageblatt" roundly accuses them of holding their tongues when the intellectual liberties of the nation were being menaced, and only coming forward when the beams of Court favour shine upon them.

An additional stimulus in favour of a spirited colonial policy is being sought in the alleged jealousy exhibited by Great Britain. And the English Press, which does not circulate, we should fancy, to any very alarming extent among the German electorate, is represented as trying to sow seeds of discord and to foment the spirit of social unrest which is so rampant in every rank of German society. The charge is ludicrous; but when we remember the credulity with which the lying tales about our soldiers were accepted during the Boer war, we feel that nothing is impossible. And the grossest calumnies against our armies and our Queen were those that found circulation among the Intellectuals and the Lutheran pastors ; Mommsen himself is a melancholy instance. Aa a nation we understand and sympathise with the German aspirations for a colonial Empire, though their present methods have been the source of no small inconvenience to ourselves, and of disturbance to tbs world at large. The Hottentot revolt in German West Africa has materially contributed to the growing unrest among the natives of that continent. The seixure of Kiaochao and the high-handed application of German rule to the Chinese led more than any single event to the Boxer rising. And if any serious endeavour is made to colonise Brazil with German emigrants, most dangerous complications with the United States are certain to ensue. Germany is known to regard the Dutch possessions in the East Indies as her ultimate heritage, and the forward school do not hesitate to hint that the British Empire overseas might do with a little lopping. We are justified, then, if we cast an anxious eye upon the proceedings of any newly-formed "League" in Germany. But if that great nation is ever to found a colonial Empire on the models which were held up by Herr Dernberg to the Intellectuals, there must be a total change in the principles of their colonial administration. Jolonics, above all things, require settlers, and no German who can possibly avoid it will submit to the petty annoyances and officialism which flourish wherever the German flag is, planted.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The Newport Rock light in Suez Ray will be changed from white to red on February 1st next.

div.head: Catarct Hotel, Assouan
div.p: The annual fancy dress ball at this hotel will be held on the 25th inst.

div.head: R.C.A.
div.p: The detachment of Royal Garrison Artillery at Alexandria will leave for Cairo tomorrow for annual training with No. 2 Company, R.G.A.

div.head: Murder at Kom Ombo.
div.p: Our Assoun correspondent reports the murder at Kom Ombo of a certain Irabi Mohamid, who was stabbed to death by Rikaby Ahmed.

div.head: The Brindial Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe, via Brindial and Port Said, will arrive at Alexandria tomorrow morning and be distributed at the G.P.O. at 8.30 a.m.

div.head: The Quay Casine.
div.p: A sitting was held yesterday of the Finance and Public Works Committee of the Alexandria Municipal Delegation and it was decided that Mr. George Ralli should furnish the plans of the new Quay Casino, of which he wants the concession, as well as a specification of the financial resources which he has at his disposal. These must be handed in within three months. The Municipality will then give decision for or against the project. Suez Bay.

div.head: Chezireh Palace Ball.
div.p: The manger Ghezireh Palace intimates that the invitations to the fancy dress ball on the 12th proxo have been issued thus early in order to afford ladies and gentlemen who intend to be present ample time to prepare their coatbmes. Guests presenting themselves in ordinary evening dress will be called upon, on entrance to the ball, to pay the sum of P.T. 40, and all such fines will be handed over to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

div.head: Stray Dogs in Cairo.
div.p: The "Journal du Caire" recently complained of the number of stray dogs in Cairo. That the allegations of our confrere are incorrect are proved by the following figures, which show how hard the Cairo police work on this most arduous duty of arresting stray or unmuzzled dogs. The number of these canine vagrants arrested in 1903 was 1,212 in 1904 2,200, in 1905 4,923 and in 1906 6,284. It will be seen that during 1906, approximately 570 were arrested montly, or 19 per diem. The statement that there "bandes de chiens sauvages" is a gross exaggeration.

div.head: English Variety Entertainment.
div.p: Alexandrians will soon have an opportunity of assisting at an English variety entertainment. Mr. Arthur Nelstone, who is described as "the world's greatest eccentric dancer," is on his way out here with a company wwhich will give an entertainment entitled "Novelty in all its Newness." Mr. Nelstone is not unknown in Egypt, having paid a previous visit to this country and met with success. Mr. Nelston made a great hit in last year's Drury Lane pantomime "Cindarella" as the "dancing sentry," contributing an extraordinarily eccentric dance. He is at present performing ini Malta, but comes on to Egypt in a few days.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCES
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut, Col. E. A. Herbert, M.V.O, and officers, the Band 6th Inniskilling Dragons will perform the following programme of music at the Grand Continental Hotel on Thursday from 4 to 6.

div.head: THE KINGSTON INCIDENT. REGRETTED IN ENGLAND. EXCHANGE OF CORDIAL TELEGRAMS
div.p: Messrs. Bcon and Taft have conferred with Mr. Roosevelt with reference to the Kingston incident. It is officially stated that the United States will not pay any attention to Sir James Swettenham's act, which they consider merely as that of an individual, and for which Great Britain can in no wise be held responsible. (Reuter)

Mr. Haldane wired to Mr. Root: "I have read in the newspapers what purports to be a latter from the Governor of Jamaica and can only say as one responsible for the troops in the island that I entertain deep gratitude for the generous assistance rendered by Admiral Davis during the most critical time."

Mr. Bacon replied that the President greatly apprecitates the cordial telegram. He is glad if the proziximity of the United States to Jamaica made it possible to be the slightest assistance If he can render further aid the President "earnestly hope that you will unhesitatingly call upon him knowing how cheerfully you would render such aid were the circumstatnces reveresed."

The Swettenham incident is all the more regretted in England in view of Admiral Davis's past friendliness with England. As a member of the Dogger Commission he turned the scale in favour of Great Britain. (Reuter)
The Mayor has received a telegram from the Mayor of Kingston dated 21st instant, appealing to the generosity of the American people for help which, he said, was most urgently needed. (Reuter)
H.M.S. Indefatigable has arrived and landed a quantity of supplies.
Sir J. Swettenham cabled to Mr. Root on the 20th instant that Jamaica was profoundly grateful for his sympathy and for the practifcal and kindly aid given by Admiral Davis and the squadron. (Feuter)

div.head: RECALL OF SQUADRONS.
div.p: The Franco-Spanish squadron will withdraw tomorrow. One French warship will remain as a precautionary measure. (Reuter)
The Note concerted between France and Spain, announcing the racll of the squadrons from Morocco, expresses the hope that the Maghzen will facilitate the organisation of the police. (Havas)

div.head: FRENCH BILLS.
div.p: The Government has apporved the bill for the completion of the Yunnan railway, and also a bill greatly facilitating the holding of services in churches. (Reuter)

div.head: SECOND HAGUE CONFERENCE
div.p: Professor Martens, on a special mission from the Tsar, has started to visit the European capitals to arragne the preliminaries of a second Hague Conference. (Reuter)

div.head: ITALIAN AMBASSADOR AT TOKIO.
div.p: Count Galliens has been appointed Italian Ambassador at Tokio. (Reuter)

div.head: FRENCHMAN MURDERED NEAR DJIBOUTI
div.p: The natives have murdered two Frenchman in the neighborhood of Djibouti. One was Ensign Perbien, who was going to Madagascar on board the Descartes. (Havas)

div.head: ARCTIC WEATHER IN EUROPE.
div.p: Arctic weather is being experienced throughout eastern and central Europe. Heavy falls of snow have taken place at Constantinople and Athens. (Reuter)

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit within certain necessary limits free discussion.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA EXCAVATIONS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Dear sir, I should like to ascertain, through the medium of your valued paper, whether there is any explanation for the great quantity of broken pottery which is constatnly being excavated, and which can be seen on the surface of the ground in many places about Alexandria. I have in mind most particularly the ground about Ibrahimieh, which in many places is covered with the borken bits of red earthenware.
One reason I have heard was that the old Egyptians destroyed all their potterly yearly when the Nile ross.
I would be very glad to hear from others interested in the mattter.
ENQUIRER.
Alexandria, January 23.
